title-group.article-title: Corn starch nanocomposite films reinforced with nanocellulose

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The need for flexible food packaging has increased substantially in recent years around the world due to the unprecedented growth in food consumption . Due to low cost and ease of processing, petroleum -based synthetic polymer packaging materials are being predominantly used for food packaging these days. To avoid contributing to environmental problems caused by ecological risks, consumers have been searching for alternatives to plastic food packaging due to the fact that plastics cannot be recycled and are not biodegradable . Therefore, bioplastics made from corn starch , which are biodegradable, can be one solution to these issues. The starch’s amylopectin and amylase composition has a significant impact on the polysaccharide’s characteristics. Corn starch (CS) is utilized as a food source for humans and other animals, but it also has many other applications in industry. Corn starch, on the other hand, has a few issues that need to be addressed through some modifications. Although starch-based packaging is expensive, they create less waste overall, which helps in the reduction amount of plastic pollution. A variety of natural and synthetic polymers – including polysaccharide-based materials like Kappaphycus alvarezii seaweed, collagen, alginate, chitosan, zein, cellulose, gelatin, various amino acids and polymeric materials like acrylic acid, polybutylene (PB), polyacrylic acid, polyethylene (PE), polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), and polycaprolactone (PCL) – are used as starch modifiers to produce polymers with a starch base that are completely biodegradable. These biopolymers have the potential to replacing petroleum-based polymers in a variety of commercial and industrial settings. Besides, corn starch nanocomposite films reinforced with nanocellulose have been investigated as a potential eco-friendly packaging material. Consequently, the effects of nanocellulose content on the mechanical , thermal, and barrier properties of corn starch-based films will be discussed in this work.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymers offer remarkable qualities and benefits linked to packing, and they have been utilized for a wide range of uses for a very long time [ 1]. Due to its low production costs, superior mechanical , and thermal properties, and abundance, it is one of the most widely used materials in the world today [ 2]. The most extensively utilised polyolefins are polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP). Yet, since PP and PE are not biodegradable , their single usage contributes to the environmental issue when they are disposed of in landfills [ 3, 4]. Another issue that arises from the use of these plastics is the fact that they are derived from non-renewable resources derived from petroleum [ 5].

To enhance the mechanical and barrier qualities of starch-based biodegradable packaging sheets, numerous techniques have been developed [ 6]. These include: (1) replacement of the strong connections between hydroxyl groups with hydrogen bonds formed with starch by the inclusion of additional plasticizers , like urea and formamide to help in the thermoplastic process and boost product flexibility, (2) the addition of synthetic biodegradable polymers results in materials with qualities midway between the two components; the resulting blends can be processed more effectively by extrusion or film blowing and have mechanical and barrier capabilities superior to those of starch alone, and (3) the inclusion of compatibilizers to improve the properties of the blend by reducing the interfacial energy and increasing the miscibility of two incompatible phases. Biodegradable polymers include polyhydroxyalkanoate, cellulosics, polylactic acid, starch- and protein-based plastics, polybutylene succinate, polycaprolactone (PCL), polybutylene adipate-co-terephthalate, polyvinyl alcohol (PVOH), polytrimethylene terephthalate, polyglycolic acid, and polyethylene oxide [ 5, 7, 8].

Both linear and highly branched amylopectin are polysaccharides that make up starch. Amylose and amylopectin ratios vary depending on the plant source, which has an impact on the starch’s physical characteristics and gelatinization patterns. Hydrogen interactions between molecules and amylose chains allow starch to form films [ 9]. In addition, these interactions may contribute to the nanoparticles achieving a higher level of stability [ 10], [ 11], [ 12]. Owing to the combined advantages such as low cost and easy availability, starch which is a natural polymer is regarded as the most potential options [ 13]. The granular structure of starch must be disrupted entirely or partially in order to create thermoplastic starch (TPS ), which is done at high temperatures, pressures, and in the presence of plasticizers [ 14]. To increase the processability and thermoplastic properties of starch, some plasticizers including sorbitol, water, sugar, and glycerol were utilized. However, due to its hydrophilic nature and high Tg, it has a limited water resistance, which limits its applicability in packing.

The most common source of plant residues is corn, which offers a number of advantages such as high starch levels, outstanding uniformity, performance, ease of availability, and biodegradability [ 15]. In order to create biodegradable films, corn starch (CS), which is the most abundant feedstock and is inexpensive, has received all of the attention. In addition, due to its high amylose content, CS possesses effective film-forming qualities. Contrary to other polymers, CS-based plastics have a number of disadvantages, such as weak mechanical properties and limited stability brought on by water absorption [ 1]. In order to improve the mechanical characteristics of the film, researchers have been looking at the possibility of incorporating nanoparticles into the matrix [ 16]. The usage of montmorillonite , nanocellulose fibers, and starch nanocrystals has been frequent in the development of nanocomposite materials [ 17], [ 18], [ 19], [ 20]. These nanoparticles successfully increased the composite films’ mechanical characteristics, barrier properties, and thermal stability [ 21]. This paper aim to review the nanocellulose reinforced CS.

sec.title: Corn plant
sec.p: Many communities developed their civilization through the farming, living in one place and cultivation of corn, as it was observed from the archaeological data that the cultivation of corn started from 2000 to 2500 B.C.E [ 22]. From then, corn crop has become the staple or part of food for most humans and animals. As per the statistics, 36 million hectares of corn was cultivated in USA in the year of 2014 and the production reached a quantity of 347.79 million metric tonnes (MMT) in USA during the year 2019 [ 23]. Across the world, the cultivation of corn has reached a very huge quantity than any other crops. It was shown in the estimates that the cultivation of corn was about 737 MMT between 2005 and 2007, when compared with the rice and wheat production which were about 92 and 122 MMT respectively. This difference in cultivation of corn and other crops is also predicted to continue in future [ 23]. Corn plants contains various parts including stalk , bottom roots, corn ear, silks, top tassel and husk [ 24– 26]. Corn kernel structure is made of six physical parts, including the hull which is the source of the fiber [ 27, 28], cap tip, horny starch and gluten, germ and the white starch [ 29]. The hull, the stalk, the husk, the starch, and the cob are all distinct components of the corn plant as shown in Figure 1 . Most importantly, corn stalk, cob and corn husk are considered to be the salient sources of fibers when compared to other parts of the corn plant [ 30– 32] ( Figure 1).

sec.title: Extraction and synthesis of corn starch
sec.p: There are many advantages of using corn as a source of plant leftovers, including its high starch content, outstanding uniformity, performance, ease of availability, and biodegradability [ 33, 34]. The corn plant is made up of one or more stems that are joined together by a few small roots. At each node of the branch, there are inflorescences. Plant parts are harvested and then made into disposable garbage. Major starch, a type of alpha-linked glucose – that is frequently employed in food manufacturers as a gelling, water-retention, and bulking agent – is mostly derived from corn. Corn fibers are distinct from other agricultural bio-products in that they save costs by up to 90 % and are widely accessible, in comparison to the availability and accessibility of other natural fibers [ 19].

The method of extracting corn starch from corn involves doing any one of the following steps: Using sediment separation technique in which the centrifugation of starch has been carried out after steeping the stalk at a temperature of 45 °C for about 24–72 h [ 35]; Using a simple centrifugation technique, steeping the corn stalks at a temperature of 50 °C for a time period of 20–24 h [ 36]; Using decantation technique, the steeping of corn stalks were carried out for 30 min duration [ 37].

sec.title: Physical and chemical structure of CS
sec.p: Corn starch (CS) is a complex carbohydrate that is widely used in the food industry as a thickener, a stabilizer, and a binder. It is a white, odorless powder that is extracted from the endosperm of corn kernels. The CS has the following chemical composition: 10.45 % moisture, 7.12 % crude lipids, 24.6 % amylose, 74.36 % amylopectin, and 0.61 % char. Table 1 shows the composition of physical and chemical properties of CS.

caption.p: Composition of chemical and physical characteristics of CS [ 38].

sec.p: In general, Corn starch comprises of two major components namely amylopectin and amylose. Amylose is a linear chain of glucose molecules that is tightly coiled and forms a helix structure. It makes up about 20–30 % of the total starch content in corn starch . Amylose is responsible for the gelling properties of corn starch and contributes to the viscosity of solutions made with corn starch.

Amylopectin, on the other hand, is a highly branched chain of glucose molecules. It accounts for around 70–80 % of the total starch content in corn starch . Amylopectin not only influences the texture of items created with corn starch but also contributes to the thickening qualities. The physical structure of corn starch can be observed under a microscope. It consists of granules that vary in size from 5 to 100 μm. The granules are mostly oval or spherical in shape and have a distinctive birefringence pattern under polarized light. The size and shape of the granules can affect the functional properties of corn starch, such as its ability to gel, thicken, and bind.

The chemical structure of corn starch is made up of glucose molecules that are linked together by alpha-1,4 alpha-1, and 6 glycosidic bonds. The alpha-1,4 glycosidic bonds form the linear chains of amylose, while the alpha-1,6 glycosidic bonds form the branching points of amylopectin. The arrangement of these bonds determines the physical and chemical properties of corn starch.

Corn starch can be modified chemically to improve its functional properties. Common modifications include cross-linking, hydroxypropylation, and acetylation. Cross-linking can improve the stability of corn starch under high temperatures and acidic conditions. Hydroxypropylation can increase the solubility and viscosity of corn starch, whereas Acetylation can increase the thermal stability and water-holding capacity of corn starch.

According to the previous research, corn grain has a protein content ranging from 8.2 to 11.6 %, a cellulose and hemicellulose content of 10.6 %, a sugar level of 2.1 %, and an ash concentration of 1.6 %. On the other hand, the starch percentage of corn grain ranges from 38 to 75 % [ 39– 41]. During the process of starch isolation, corn hull fiber remains as residual contents and alkalization and some other methods were used for extraction of corn fibers after chemical treatment [ 42– 44]. Table 2 enlists the physical characteristics and the chemical composition of CS.

caption.p: Chemical composition and physical characteristics of CS [ 42, 45– 48].

sec.title: Classification of fiber: corn
sec.p: The term “natural fibers " generally refers to a variety of classification of fiber that originated from nature sources such as plants, minerals, and animals [ 49]. As a result, it is of the utmost importance to clarify that the term “natural fibers” referred to “plant fibers” in the current research [ 50, 51]. Moreover, “Plant fibers” are also referred to as “lignocellulosic fibers,” “cellulosic fibers,” or “vegetable fibers.” Fabrics, twines, and ropes made from natural fibers have been used extensively in human society ever since they were first introduced. They may be also utilised without harming the environment or depleting resources because they are renewable, biodegradable , and carbon neutral. Natural fibers can be divided into three categories based on their sources: mineral, animal, and plant. Plant fibers can be divided into two primary categories: wood and non-wood bio-fiber which shown in Figure 2.

Table 3 shows the characteristics of corn cob , husk , hull , and corn stalk . When compared to other prominent sources of natural fibers such as wheat straw, husk and barn as well as rice straw and husk, it is evident that corn husk and cob have a high content of cellulose [ 53– 74].

caption.p: Physical characteristics and chemical composition of corn cob , husk , hull , and corn stalk [ 42, 65, 68– 70, 75– 83].

sec.title: Cellulose fiber
sec.p: Cellulose , a semicrystalline polymer made of poly(1,4-D-anhydroglucopyranose) units, is the primary component of plant fibers [ 34]. Strong hydrogen bonds between hydroxyl groups help to generate these units. Lignin and hemicellulose are two additional important constituents of the structure of natural fibers. Hemicellulose is comprised of a wide variety of sugars, including galactose, arabinose, mannose, and xylose, whereas lignin is a highly cross-linked phenolic polymer. Lignin and hemicellulose, however, are both amorphous polymers . The removal of the amorphous region and isolation of NCCs from natural fibers can be accomplished using the well-known method of strong acid hydrolysis. Acid hydrolysis enables removal of the amorphous portions of cellulose fibers under controlled conditions while preserving the crystalline domains as crystalline nanoparticles. In actuality, eliminating the amorphous region affects the fibers’ structure, thermal stability, crystallinity, and surface shape.

sec.title: Nanocellulose fiber
sec.p: In the past few years, nanocellulose had been produced using cellulose fiber from several sources, such as sugar palm, corn, water hyacinth, oil palm empty fruit bunch (OPEFB), ramie, pineapple leaf, kenaf bast, roselle, cotton, and sugarcane bagasse. Modifying cellulose at the nanoscale is one method for enhancing its performance [ 34]. There are several ways to make nanocellulose, one of which includes chemical (pulping, bleaching, and acid hydrolysis) and mechanical treatments (ultrasonication, high shear homogenization, and high-pressure homogenization). The attractive inherent properties of nanocrystalline celluloses (NCCs ) extracted from plant fibers– including their availability, renewability, biodegradability, large surface area (100 m 2/g 1), high aspect ratio of 100, high crystallinity, low density, and high mechanical strength have generated plenty of interest in material science [ 84]. Strong acid hydrolysis is frequently used to separate NCCs from natural fibers in order to get rid of the amorphous area. Acid hydrolysis allows for the removal of the amorphous components of cellulose fibers while maintaining the crystalline domains as crystalline nanoparticles.

sec.title: Plasticization of corn starch films
sec.p: If starch is combined with enough non-aqueous plasticizer (generally polyols) or water, it can be transformed into a thermoplastic polymer. Polyols including glycerol, diethylene glycol, ethylene glycol, polyethylene glycol, propylene glycol, sorbitol, and triethylene glycol are the most often utilised hydrophilic plasticizers in starch-based films [ 85]. Plasticizers are a special category of non-volatile low molecular weight chemicals as well as a special kind of polymer additive. Enhancing the flexibility and fracture resistance of films made of starch is the primary function of plasticizers. Other characteristics were also affected, including crystallinity, permeability to water vapor, and biodegradation. Pure starch films were exceedingly fragile and quickly fractured when handled. Plasticizers are introduced in the right amounts during the film-making process to solve these issues. Plasticizers can diminish the interaction of starch molecules, reduce the stiffness and tensile strength of films, and increase the liquidity of starch-based films [ 86].

In order to enhance the applicability and flexibility of the starch-based bio composites, plasticizers are generally employed. Since the starch molecules could not be melted in its raw form as hydrogen bonds are present within them, plasticizers were used to impregnate into the starch molecules, breaking the hydrogen bonds at higher pressure, temperature and shear stress [ 87]. It was reported in a variety of published literature that the most prevalent types of plasticizers for starch were ethanolamine, diethanolamine, ethylene glycol, and triethanolamine [ 88]. Glycerol is the plasticizer which is prevalently used since it decreases the glass transition temperature of the starch, and thus reduces the strength of the intermolecular hydrogen bonding among the starch molecules [ 89]. Additionally, glycerol enhances the value of elongation at break and improves the ease of processing of the starch [ 90]. Nevertheless, the presence of glycerol as a plasticizer in the starch reduces the mechanical properties of the final biocomposites [ 91, 92].

Plasticizers are usually incorporated into the starch molecules for enhancing their flexibility, plasticity and decreasing the biocomposite material’s brittleness. It has been claimed in some research studies that the incorporation of plasticizers into bio composites is required in order to prevent an undesirable decline in the mechanical characteristics of bio composites that do not contain plasticizers. Some researchers strengthened corn starch by adding 8 % corn husk , leading to a 615 MPa in modulus of elasticity and 13 MPa in tensile strength values. Hybridization of the corn starch composites with 6 % of sugar palm fibers enhanced the mechanical properties of the hybrid composites. Tensile strength of the hybrid composites was noted to be 19 MPa and the elasticity modulus reached a value of 1162 MPa. It was also noted that the highest value of elongation at break was obtained for the biocomposites without the sugar palm fibers [ 93, 94].

In some experiments, corn starch was plasticized with a glycerol mixture and polyol mixtures containing a high molecular weight polyol (HP) including sorbitol, maltitol, and xylitol. The bio composites with a glycerol concentration of 40 parts per hundred (PHR) showed the greatest tensile strength value, at 9.3 MPa, when glycerol was added. Similarly, the high value of elongation at break (EB) was obtained as 118 % at 60 PHR glycerol content. When sorbitol was used as a plasticizer, the highest achieved tensile strength value was 10.4 MPa for a sorbitol content of 50 % in the mixture of polyol, while the EB value reached a highest value of 105 % for 10 % sorbitol content in the polyol mixture. It was also noted that for 20 % glycerol and malitol mixture, a high tensile strength value of 16.27 MPa was recorded [ 95]. Upon addition of the plasticizer, the breakage of hydrogen bonds occurred which allows the free movement of the molecules, thus increasing the elongation at break. The maximum value of tensile strength was also achieved when starch-plasticizer bonds prevailed over the hydrogen bonds produced between starch molecules [ 17].

sec.title: Corn starch blend
sec.p: CS blends were characterized in terms of their average molecular weight, content of moisture, thermal stability through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), water solubility, chemical composition through IR spectroscopy (FTIR), chemical characteristics and phase change characteristics through X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), antimicrobial, mechanical , and microstructural characteristics, and their solubility in alkaline and acidic mediums [ 96]. Oliveira et al. [ 97] developed biodegradable polymer blends based on corn starch and thermoplastic chitosan processed by extrusion . The researchers stated that the blends also showed good thermal stability, and the addition of chitosan resulted in more thermally stable films. Furthermore, SEM images of the blends revealed uniform surfaces, and the criofractured samples exhibited no evidence of chitosan clumping within a totally destructurized starch matrix. The phase transition point in the blending system depends on the blending ratio and solution concentration. The reduction in tensile modulus was discovered to be correlated with the lower transparency point of the mix and phase transition region of hydroxypropyl methylcellulose/hydroxypropyl starch composite from continuous phase to separated phase [ 98]. The blend system was discovered by the authors to be immiscible, with a phase transition point that depends on the blending ratio and solution concentration. Gutiérrez and Alvarez [ 96] studied the properties of native and oxidized corn starch/polystyrene (PS) blends with zinc octanoate catalyst prepared using reactive extrusion technique. The findings make it abundantly clear that the catalyst utilized was responsible for the formation of cross-links between the starch and PS. Besides, the oxidative alteration of the starch increased the substance’s tendency for chemical activity. A modified system of starch is produced when the starch structures are supplemented with carbonyl and carboxyl groups. This results in the starch having a higher degree of hydrophobicity. Tian et al. [ 99] experimented on the blends of PVA/corn starch using nanoclay intercalation techniques and observed that the thermal and mechanical characteristics of the bio composites were increased. The strong bond between montmorillonite (MMT) nanolayers and PVA/starch macromolecules may limit the matrix’s swelling capacity and hence reduce water absorption. In contrast, the mixture exhibited excellent stability and compatibility when it was combined with electrolyte solutions. Furthermore, the swelling behavior tests revealed that the hydrogel beads had exceptional water absorption capacities [ 100].

sec.title: Corn starch bilayer films
sec.p: Because they are resistant to rapid biodegradation, the newly developed bilayer films have potential for use in studies aimed at improving food packaging [ 101]. Chen et al. [ 102] demonstrated that bilayer film has an adhesive interface between the two layers and smooth surface shape with better visibility. Tensile strength and Young’s modulus of the bilayer film were significantly increased as compared to the monolayer film. Zuo et al. [ 103] studied the physical and structural characterization of edible bilayer films made with zein and corn-wheat starch. The addition of zein has an impact on the visual appeal and physical characteristics of films. The authors found that the opacity, WVP, and TS were decreased, whereas the water content, E and antioxidative capacity were increased. The biodegradation test revealed that PLA and TPS biodegrade more quickly than other materials [ 104]. Scanning electron microscopy revealed robust linkages between the bilayer films and demonstrated the disappearance and reappearance of the network structure inside the films [ 105]. In comparison to net starch films, a significant improvement was made in tensile and water vapor barrier properties. The films maintained high transparency and oxygen permeability as low as starch films, despite the lower ratio of cast PLA sheet in the bilayer assembly (approximately one third of the film thickness). This, in fact, is the main cause of improving the tensile and water vapor barrier properties [ 106]. Zhou et al. [ 107] developed and characterized pea starch and PLA bilayer films for their potential application in the packaging of cherry tomatoes. The authors found that the addition of two layers improved the PS films’ water resistance (lower water absorption and solubility), thermal characteristics, and water vapor barrier (lower WVP). However, the laminated structure’s synergy effect improved the mechanical and barrier properties of bilayer films, making them a good choice for packaging foods that absorb a lot of moisture. The bilayer films’ tensile strength (TS) and elongation at break (EAB) increased by 74.04 % and 348.13 %, respectively [ 108]. Due to the hydrophobic property of the PLA layer, the integration of the PLA layer greatly decreased the water vapor permeability, water absorption, and solubility of bilayer films [ 109].

sec.title: Fiber reinforced corn starch biocomposites
sec.p: Biocomposites are a promising alternative, based on corn, to traditional composites made from non-renewable materials such as fiberglass and carbon fiber [ 110– 113]. These biocomposites are made by combining corn-based polymers with natural fibers such as corn husks, corn stalks, and corn cobs. Table 4 enlists the mechanical characteristics of corn-based biocomposites. In terms of mechanical properties, Corn -based biocomposites have demonstrated high tensile strength , stiffness, and impact resistance. From the table it can be observed that the corn husk (CH) hybridized with sugar palm fiber reinforced corn starch resulted high tensile properties of 19 MPa compared to others reinforcement. The natural fibers in the composites provide reinforcement, while the corn-based polymers act as a matrix to hold the fibers together. This material combination produces a lightweight, robust, and long-lasting composite material. However, the mechanical properties of corn-based bio-composites can vary depending on factors such as the type and proportion of natural fibers used, processing methods, and environmental conditions. Further, more research is needed to optimize the mechanical properties of these bio-composites and ensure their long-term durability and reliability.

tr.td: Blend of CS and soy protein isolate (SPI)
Corn husk (CH) hybridized with sugar palm fiber

sec.p: The water vapor barrier, mechanical , and optical properties of Kappaphycus alvarezii seaweed and corn starch blend bio composite films were investigated, Khalil et al. [ 116]. The researchers stated that the concentration of seaweed had the biggest impact on the mechanical and optical behavior of the seaweed/starch biocomposite films. However, the water vapor permeability of the composite films improved with increasing amounts of starch and seaweed. Besides that, the FTIR measurement also showed intermolecular interactions between the two compounds, which is in line with the high miscibility degree between the seaweed and the starch in the mixture. The primary peak shift in FTIR to higher wavenumbers and the decrease in crystallinity in XRD are evidences that starch molecules and chitosan may interact via hydrogen bonding [ 117]. Besides, Ren et al. [ 117] stated that the film’s solubility, tensile properties, elasticity, and water vapor permeability (WVP) of the film were increased with the inclusion of natural fiber. Wang et al. [ 118] researched on water solubility index and mechanical characteristics of collagen-corn starch biocomposite films, as well as the evaluation of effects of concentration and type of starch. The authors found that the addition of starch to collagen enhanced the composite films’ thickness and opacity. Furthermore, the surface of starch-collagen films was rougher than that of pure collagen films, which smoothed out during heating, according to image taken using scanning electron microscopy. SEM image were reported in Figure 3.

caption.p: SEM micrographs of collagen and collagen-based biocomposite film surface (a) before heating, (b) after heating at a scale of 20 µm; (c) cross section of biocomposite film before heating, and (d) after heating at a scale of 50 µm. Collagen film blended with corn starch (I) 10 wt%, (II) 50 wt% and hybridized with (a) high amylose content, (b) waxy corn starch content, (c) without starch, and (d) neat collagen composites [ 118].

sec.title: Cellulose reinforced corn starch biocomposites
sec.p: Wang et al. [ 98] reported the relationship between morphologies and mechanical properties of hydroxypropyl methylcellulose (HPMC)/hydroxypropyl starch blends. It was revealed by the researchers that as the concentration of the solution increased the modulus and elongation both dropped. This finding is consistent with the observed morphologies, in which it was determined that the HPMC progressively transitioned from a continuous phase to a discrete phase. However, the modulus and elongation both decreased with increasing solution concentration; this is probably due to HPMC’s gradual transition from a continuous to a separated phase. Figure 4 shows the modulus and elongation at break of HPMC.

caption.p: Modulus and elongation at break of HPMC [ 98].

sec.title: Microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) reinforced corn starch
sec.p: Fabra et al. [ 119] experimented on the microalgae reinforced in the thermoplastic corn starch films and evaluated their physicochemical and structural characteristics. The kind of microalgae and, more specifically, the degree of cell wall disintegration influence considerably the mechanical characteristics of the biocomposites. With the addition of the various microalgae species, a loss in water permeability of around 54 % was observed.

sec.title: Nanocellulose reinforced corn starch
sec.p: One of the novel nanomaterials obtained from the natural lignocellulosic fibers, which could be considered for the potential reinforcement material in the biopolymers to produce green composites, is nanocellulose. When the cellulose polymer is disintegrated to nanoscale range (10 −9 m), it is called nanocellulose. Cotton stalks and fibers, coconut fibers, algae, sugarcane bagasse, and other natural fibers are some of the primary agro biomass -based sources to produce cellulose. Good quality nanocellulose can be extracted from the cotton linter which is the by-product of the textile and is considered to the rich source of pure form of cellulose. When compared to other natural fibers, the process of removal of non-cellulosic components like hemicellulose and lignin from the cotton fibers is relatively easier. There are many reasons why NC could be used as a reinforcement material in green polymer matrices, including their high tensile strength (2–10 GPa), higher surface to volume ratio (55–205 m 2/g), excellent thermal stability (225–330 °C), very low density (1.32–1.46 g/cm 3), better rheological properties, hydrophilicity, biodegradability and renewability, high degree of crystallinity, and chemical compatibility. When nanocellulose (NC) was used as reinforcement in biopolymer-based biocomposites, the water barrier and mechanical properties of the biocomposites were found to be enhanced.

Patil et al. [ 120] studied the corn starch biocomposites films made of nanocellulose reinforcements. Cotton linters were used for the synthesis of NC through chemo-mechanical process which were then used as a reinforcement to manufacture the functionally improved biocomposite films. Chemo-mechanical technique involves the acid hydrolysis of cotton linters after bleaching, and homogenizing them under ultra-high pressure as depicted in Figure 5.

Particle size analysis of the NC materials indicated that a particle size of 55.4 nm was there for almost 93.7 % of the particles while the remaining particles had an average particle size of 1103 nm as shown in Figure 6a. Colloidal stability of the suspension could be determined by testing the Zeta potential of the material. The absolute value of zeta potential for a stable suspension in any material should be 20 mV. As shown in Figure 6b, the average value of zeta potential portrayed by the NC suspension was about 29.06 mV, indicating the production of stable colloidal material of NC from cotton linter using chemo-mechanical technique. It was also observed from the experimental results that the developed NC material was in nanoscale range. Figure 6c illustrates the atomic force microscopic (AFM) analysis of the NC material which further acknowledges the nano-size of NC. After analyzing an AFM image of NC material with the help of Image J software, it has been found that its particles had an average size of 86 nm and a standard deviation of 33 nm.

caption.p: Nanocellulose characterization (a) particle size analysis, (b) zeta potential analysis, and (c) 3D atomic force microscopic images.

sec.p:
Few experimenters studied the effect of incorporation of NC at different weight fractions along with different plasticizers in the starch films synthesized using solvent casting method. The tensile strength (TS), elongation at break (EB), water vapor permeability (WVP), and bursting strength (BS) were taken as responses, as well as were optimized using response surface methodology. As per the optimization results, 1.89 % of polyvinyl alcohol (PVOH), 2.54 % of glycerol (GL), and 0.9 % of NC resulted in the optimum formulation of biocomposite film with better properties. As shown in Figures 7
– 10, the predicted responses were 8.93 MPa of TS, 41.95 % of EB, 5.57 kPa of BS and 7.09 × 10 −10 g/msPa of WVP. P-value of the optimization showed that the NC reinforcement influenced the mechanical and other properties significantly with a confidence limit of 0.95. It was also shown in the results that the NC, extracted from the cotton linters, enhanced the mechanical properties of the biocomposite films. Nano size of NC, huge surface area, and strength of the hydrogen bonds formed between starch, were stated to be reasons for the high tensile strength of the biocomposite films. The load bearing capacity of the NC-based composites improved due to the increased mechanical strength and high aspect ratio of the NC. This improved the stress transfer from the matrix of the composites to the NC, which in turn increased the biocomposite film’s resistance to breaking [ 121– 125]. It was also portrayed in the experimental results that the effect of NC addition on TS and EB are inversely proportional to each other. Owing to the chemical and structural compatibility between starch and NC, the addition of NC had a negative effect on the EB of the biocomposite films. But this in turn increased the toughness of the composites through the strengthening of interactions between NC-starch bonds. Few experimenters reported the EB reduced for the starch-based films because of the rigidity of the cellulose nanocrystals [ 126, 127]. Some experimenters stated that the gradual addition of higher content of PVOH and GL into NC might result in the increase of EB of the composites [ 120]. Since the GL minimizes the intermolecular forces existing between starch molecules through its plasticizing effect when reinforced in higher contents, the flexibility of the biocomposite films increase considerably. In addition, as depicted in Figure 9c, a number of researchers reported that TS and EB had beneficial effects as a result of NC reinforcement, whereas BS had an adverse impact and the quadratic effect had a favorable outcome as a result of reinforcement. The BS value of the biocomposite film dropped with increasing NC content up to a certain point, but after that point, it grew along with NC content, as seen by the convex curved surfaces in Figure 9c. Owing to the high surface area of the NC, BS of the composite films increased resulting in a better starch-NC interfacial adhesion which in turn increased the strength of NC films [ 128– 133].

caption.p: 3D surface plot showing the variation of tensile strength of thermoplastic corn starch based composite films with the composition of various blends.
3D surface plot showing the variation of elongation at break of thermoplastic corn starch based composite films with the composition of various blends.
3D surface plot showing the variation of bursting strength of thermoplastic corn starch based composite films with the composition of various blends.
3D surface plot showing the variation of water vapor permeability of thermoplastic corn starch based composite films with the composition of various blends.

sec.p: The addition of NC content in the biocomposites restricted the permeation of water molecules inside the films and impacted WVP properties to a larger extent. As seen in Figure 10, the WVP of the biocomposites decreased with the increase in NC contents. The transmission of water vapor through the hydrophilic film is governed by the solubility and diffusivity of the water molecules within the biocomposite film matrix [ 134]. Water vapor barrier of the composite films were increased and the diffusivity of the composites were decreased by the high aspect ratio of the NC. A rugged pathway was created by the reinforced NC in the polymer matrix which reduces the movement of water by decreasing the diffusion rate of water vapor into the composite [ 135]. Due to the rigid hydrogen bonding formed due to the high crystallinity of the NC molecules, the pore size of the biocomposites reduced the water diffusion and increased the water vapor barrier properties [ 136]. The results given by some experimenters suggested that the NC reinforced corn starch -based biocomposite films can be used effectively for storing the edible oil for a longer duration without significantly deteriorating the oil quality in ambient conditions [ 120]. Due to the high-water vapor permeability properties of these biocomposite films, this application was quite possible. It is a well-known fact that the material used for packaging must possess a low oxygen and water vapor permeability which avoids the oxidation of oil during their storage. Hence, these NC-based corn starch biocomposite films can be potentially used as a packaging material for edible oil storage.

sec.title: Application, challenges and future perspective
sec.p: One of the major advantages in utilizing the agricultural crop corn as a precursor for biocomposite manufacturing is the renewability of the agricultural-based products. But unless the green cover of the forest is continuously renewed and regenerated, the use of forest plants to produce biocomposites cannot be completely utilized and would be restricted. Various types of papers and paper-boards can be derived from the corn-based straws and fibers due to the presence of high amount of lignin in those crops. Since lignin is characterized by a fuel value and high content of energy, it can be used for burning of fuel. Application of lignin extends to the manufacturing of binders and adhesives despite their low values [ 137]. Corn -based biocomposites are utilized for manufacturing day-to-day products such as packaging pads, loose fills, foam cushioning, mailer bags, paper padding, and air cushioning.

Applications for nano and micro cellulose, which can be extracted from corn fibers and other fiber sources, are expanding rapidly. As an additive, micro and nano fibrillated cellulose is used in many different industries, including those dealing with cosmetics, paper production, chronic wound healing, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, flexible electronics, coatings, sanitary pads, and high-temperature insulation and thermal barrier applications [ 138– 142]. Owing to various advantageous features like small diameter along the vascular grafts, nanocrystalline cellulose (NCC) was used in medical applications, packaging applications, synthetic plastics or polymers, electronic applications, catalysis, filtration applications, fuel cells, solar cells, tissue engineering, and lithium-ion batteries. Because of their high tensile strength and low thermal expansion, NCC-based biocomposites are used in applications like automobile components and fire extinguishers [ 143– 148]. Microcrystalline cellulose-based biocomposites are also utilized as abrasives in cosmetics, bulking applications, absorbent in water treatment, anti-caking agents, viscosity aqueous raising agents, emulsion stabilizer, binder, texturizer, and slip modifiers [ 149].

The hydroxyl groups must be altered through surface modification, grafting, or esterification in order to increase the versatility of hydrophilic polymers made from starch and cellulosic fiber. It is important to pay attention to the choice of fiber size since it has an impact on the molecular bonds that are formed and control the characteristics of the final product. Indeed, CS offers a wide variety of amylose content, offering specific design, and conditions to complete the fabrication process in every desired application.

Plastic will eventually be replaced by biodegradable packaging materials for food packaging . Future work will focus on improving the mechanical properties of bioplastics made from renewable bioresources, which are an important possibility. Studies on nanotechnology, in particular, will play a significant role here. For instance, a substance that is inexpensive and has excellent mechanical qualities will enhance the possibility that it will be transformed into such substances as nanotechnology develops. As a result, in the next centuries, the special qualities of bio-nanocomposites made from renewable sources should be the main place to look for new potential and applications for green nanomaterials . Future applications for these nanocomposites with enhanced biocompatibility, biodegradability, and mechanical and thermal qualities include numerous aspects of daily life.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Corn starch (CS) is a polymer that occurs naturally. CS is widely accessible, affordable, and simple to alter using various physical or chemical techniques. Biopolymers minimize plastic pollution, which is one of the major threats to our environment. They have valuable applications in a variety of fields and can further replace polymers made from petroleum . Starch is combined with natural polymers (cellulose, chitosan, gelatin, alginate, hydroxyapatite, and protein), synthetic polymers (PVA, PVC, PCL, polybutylene, and polyethylene), and inorganic nanoparticles (lithium, silver, and talc) using a variety of chemical and physical techniques. Development of modified CS based bionanocomposites films with better physical and mechanical properties than simple starch-based films– including increased elasticity, break resistance, moisture adsorption capacity, low water vapor permeability value, and higher tensile strength – is one of the most technological advances in the polymer industry. In order to create high-value goods for cutting-edge applications in a variety of fields, modified CS-based polymers has a very bright future.
